bestBHT.bht: Let our people, the Cretan converts, learn to practise good works and contribute to the necessary wants which arise. By supplying the necessary wants of Christian missionaries and brethren, our ordinary opportunities are to be found of bearing fruit to God's praise. It is important for them to learn and continue to grow in their ability to do good works, so that they do not become unfruitful. Let every man consider what is his ability and according to the power which God has given, let us serve one another.

Henry Alford: Moreover, let also our people learn to practise good works, contributions to the necessary wants which arise.
Such wants as from time to time are presented before Christians, requiring relief in the course of their Father's work in life.
In the supply by us of such necessary wants our ordinary opportunities are to be found of bearing fruit to God's praise.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: supply the necessary wants of Christian missionaries and brethren
Albert Barnes: And let ours - Our friends; that is, those who were Christians Paul had just directed Titus to aid Zenas and Apollos himself, and he here adds that he wished that others who were Christians would be characterized by good works of all kinds.
For necessary uses - Such as are required by their duty to their families, and by the demands of charity; see Titus 3:8.
That they be not unfruitful - That it may be seen that their religion is not barren and worthless, but that it produces a happy effect on themselves and on society.
John Calvin: You have fine speculations, says he, but yet consider what is the true excellence of the children of God; it is to shew that they have profited well in doing good, and that this is the subject to which they have given their study.
Henceforth you must excel in doing good, and not in rambling talk. Instead of being led by curiosity and ambition, let every man be employed in doing good to his neighbors.
Let every man consider what is his ability; and according to the power which God has given us, let us serve one another. Thus shall we shew that it is not in vain that we have received the gospel.
Philip Schaff: Not Titus alone, but the Cretan brethren were to share in this fitting out of the two travellers.
Archibald T. Robertson: Our people (ο ημετερο). 'Our folks.' The Cretan converts, not just Paul's friends.
Let learn (μανθανετωσαν). Present active imperative, keep on learning how.
John Gill: By which are not only meant honest trades, as some choose to render the words... but all good works in general.

To maintain them, is to endeavor to outdo others in them, not only the men of the world, but one another; and to set examples of them to others, and to provoke one another, by a holy emulation, to them.
Good works are the fruits of the Spirit, and of his grace; they are fruits of righteousness; and such as are without them are like trees without fruit, useless and unprofitable.
John Wesley: Both by thy admonition and example.
Perhaps they had not before assisted Zenas and Apollos as they ought to have done.

bhtAttempts.bht: Let our people, the Cretan converts, learn to practice good works and contribute to the necessary wants that arise in the course of their Father's work in life. By supplying the needs of Christian missionaries and brethren, they have the opportunity to bear fruit and bring praise to God. This includes not only providing for the physical needs of others but also showing hospitality and generosity. It is important for them to learn and continue to grow in their ability to do good works, so that they do not become unfruitful. The goal is for their religion to have a real impact on themselves and society, proving that their faith is not barren or worthless. Let everyone consider their abilities and serve one another according to the power that God has given, setting examples and encouraging one another in doing good works. This is the true excellence of the children of God, who have received the gospel and are now called to excel in doing good rather than being caught up in idle talk and pursuits.

Let our people, the Cretan converts, learn to practice good works and contribute to the necessary wants that arise in the course of their Father's work in life. By supplying the necessary wants of Christian missionaries and brethren, they have the opportunity to bear fruit and bring praise to God. It is important for them to learn and continue to grow in their ability to do good works, so that they do not become unfruitful. Let everyone consider their abilities and serve one another according to the power that God has given.

This includes not only providing for the physical needs of others but also showing hospitality and generosity. It is important for them to learn and continue to grow in their ability to do good works, so that they do not become unfruitful.

Let our people, the Cretan converts, learn to practise good works and contribute to the necessary wants which arise. In the supply of such wants, ordinary opportunities are found to bear fruit to God's praise. By supplying the necessary wants of Christian missionaries and brethren, they can excel in doing good, proving that their faith is not barren or useless. It is essential for them to learn and continue in their ability to do good works, thus avoiding being unfruitful. Let every person consider their ability and serve one another accordingly.

Let our people, the Cretan converts, learn to practise good works and contribute to the necessary wants which arise. By supplying the necessary wants of Christian missionaries and brethren, our ordinary opportunities are to be found of bearing fruit to God's praise. It is important for them to learn and continue to grow in their ability to do good works, so that they do not become unfruitful. Let every man consider what is his ability and according to the power which God has given, let us serve one another.
